abstracts.cdata!:
While the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and the
            institutional development impact negligible. This is so,
            mainly because without additional measures undertaken to
            strengthen the operations of the Kenya Power and Lighting
            Company (KPLC), possibly through privatization/contract
            management, the sustainability of the power sector
            operations will be uncertain. Similarly, while the
            Government's commitment to implement the project was
            strong, it was however, weak in executing the institutional,
            and policy actions required. Lessons question the provision
            of emergency recovery support, where policy and
            institutional factors have played a role in bringing about a
            crisis situation, and if so, whether such support should be
            accompanied by reform conditions. The experience with this
            operation supports the notion that the decision should be
            based on the implications of the "with" and
            "without" emergency support scenarios on growth,
            and poverty. But since the design of emergency operations
            require implementation of mitigation measures, the
            policy/institutional related causes of the emergency would
            need to be addressed to avoid repeat disasters. Thus, by
            linking measures to implement reforms, stakeholders would be
            sensitized on important sector policy issues, and, the
            Borrower should be required to commit irreversible actions
            to be taken prior to financing approval.

5084938.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Power Supply Project in
            Kenya, will support the Government in implementing its
            emergency measures, addressing the ongoing power supply
            crisis, currently hindering economic growth, and delivery of
            social services. The project will finance the
            Government's purchases of electricity, and associated
            fuel from short-term independent power producers, and fuel
            suppliers while the power supply crisis lasts. The project
            will also finance working capital requirements, for fuel
            purchases arising from the drought-induced changes in the
            power generation mix, between hydro, and technical sources,
            and from reduced revenues caused by local shedding. The
            project will be beneficial in preventing severe economic
            contraction, and in providing fast-track reforms in power
            transmission, and distribution systems, to create a more
            competitive, and private sector-led system, as agreed under
            the Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper. Nonetheless,
            risks include the potential of unrealized net revenues from
            the domestic share of project financing, which is to be
            derived from the collection from final consumers; possible
            coordination problems between the power company, and
            independent power producers, which may delay timely power
            connections; and, possible misappropriation of funds.
            However, well established management practices may well
            reduce those risks.
